<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_connection_alloc_memory_:
```c
void *
MHD_connection_alloc_memory_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                              size_t size)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /* a short alias */
  struct MemoryPool *const pool = c->pool;     /* a short alias */
  size_t need_to_be_freed = 0; /**< The required amount of additional free memory */
  void *res;

  res = MHD_pool_try_alloc (pool,
                            size,
                            &need_to_be_freed);
  if (NULL != res)
    return res;

  if (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool,
                                     c->write_buffer,
                                     c->write_buffer_size))
  {
    if (c->write_buffer_size - c->write_buffer_append_offset >=
        need_to_be_freed)
    {
      char *buf;
      const size_t new_buf_size = c->write_buffer_size - need_to_be_freed;
      buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                 c->write_buffer,
                                 c->write_buffer_size,
                                 new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer == buf);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_append_offset <= new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_send_offset <= new_buf_size);
      c->write_buffer_size = new_buf_size;
      c->write_buffer = buf;
    }
    else
      return NULL;
  }
  else if (MHD_pool_is_resizable_inplace (pool,
                                          c->read_buffer,
                                          c->read_buffer_size))
  {
    if (c->read_buffer_size - c->read_buffer_offset >= need_to_be_freed)
    {
      char *buf;
      const size_t new_buf_size = c->read_buffer_size - need_to_be_freed;
      buf = MHD_pool_reallocate (pool,
                                 c->read_buffer,
                                 c->read_buffer_size,
                                 new_buf_size);
      mhd_assert (c->read_buffer == buf);
      mhd_assert (c->read_buffer_offset <= new_buf_size);
      c->read_buffer_size = new_buf_size;
      c->read_buffer = buf;
    }
    else
      return NULL;
  }
  else
    return NULL;
  res = MHD_pool_allocate (pool, size, true);
  mhd_assert (NULL != res); /* It has been checked that pool has enough space */
  return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
res = MHD_pool_allocate (pool, size, true);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No — not violated in this fragment. The local variable is declared as 'struct MemoryPool *const pool' (a const pointer to a non-const MemoryPool) and it is passed to MHD_pool_allocate. An allocator function normally modifies the pool internal state (allocations), so the pointee cannot reasonably be const; likewise the returned void * must be a mutable pointer. If, however, MHD_pool_allocate actually does not modify the MemoryPool, then the function signature should take a 'const struct MemoryPool *' (and/or the local pool variable should point to const), in which case this use would violate Rule 8.13.
